title: Endeavor to Jump Into Public Offering Again
summary: The Hollywood entertainment company had shelved its IPO plans in late 2019. Endeavor Group Holdings Inc. is set to go public, revealing plans to take full ownership of UFC and highlighting its transformation from a talent agency into a media conglomerate with a collection of high-profile sports and entertainment brands.

title: Microsoft, U.S. Army Strike Nearly $22 Billion Headset Deal
summary: Augmented-reality devices will be delivered over next decade, based on existing HoloLens product. Microsoft Corp. has agreed to build custom augmented-reality headsets for the U.S. Army in a deal worth up to $21.9 billion, expanding the technology company's role as a major government supplier.

title: Cuomo, Lawmakers Weigh Forcing Nursing Homes to Spend on Patients
summary: Discussions come as governor's office is under fire for how it handled Covid-19's spread in long-term-care facilities. ALBANY, N.Y.-New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo and state lawmakers are close to agreement on a law that would require nursing homes to spend a set portion of their revenue on patient care, officials said, at a time when the governor's office is under fire over how it handled Covid-19 in long-term-care facilities.

title: Robinhood to Remove Controversial Digital Confetti From Trading App
summary: The confetti, which critics alleged was a gamification strategy, will be replaced with new designs. Robinhood Markets Inc. is eliminating digital confetti from its trading app, the latest sign that the popular brokerage is working to correct concerns from critics, as it moves forward with plans to go public.

title: Russian Troop Movements on Ukraine Border Test Biden Administration
summary: After fresh fighting inside Ukraine, Kyiv puts forces on alert and bolsters units in country's east. Russia has begun mobilizing troops along its border with Ukraine, presenting a fresh challenge at the Biden administration and threatening to upend a cease-fire between Ukraine and pro-Russian fighters.

title: Here Come the Biden Taxes
summary: The middle class will pay for the largest tax increase since 1968.. So much for the illusion of cost-free spending blowouts. The bill for President Biden's agenda is coming due, starting with Wednesday's proposal for the largest corporate tax increase in decades. Can we finally drop the pretense that any of this is moderate or unifying or bipartisan?

title: Democracy Prevails in Iowa
summary: Rita Hart withdraws her challenge but complains of 'disinformation.'. Speaker Nancy Pelosi suffered her first setback of this Congress Wednesday as the drive to overturn an Iowa House election imploded. Rita Hart, the Democratic candidate challenging Republican Rep. Mariannette Miller-Meeks's victory, announced that "after many conversations with people I trust about the future of this contest, I have made the decision to withdraw."

title: Micron's Great Results Aren't Great for Chip Buyers
summary: Memory chip maker cites a 'severe undersupply,' with market expected to remain tight for the year. If Micron's numbers are any guide, the chip industry should have a strong year. Buyers of chips: less so.

title: David Chang's Momofuku Kawi Closes at Hudson Yards
summary: Restaurant is the latest dining spot in the Manhattan complex to close during the pandemic. Another high-profile business in Manhattan's Hudson Yards has closed.

title: Ford Says Chip Shortage Forcing Production Halt at Several Plants
summary: Auto maker is scheduling more downtime at some U.S. factories, including its two major truck sites. Ford Motor Co. is scheduling more downtime at several U.S. factories, including its two major truck plants, as a global shortage of semiconductors upends vehicle manufacturing for car makers in North America.

title: Biden's $2.3 Trillion Infrastructure Plan Takes Broad Aim
summary: Proposal would increase corporate taxes to pay for fixing roads and bridges, boosting research and tackling climate change. WASHINGTON-President Biden unveiled a $2.3 trillion infrastructure plan centered on fixing roads and bridges, expanding broadband internet access and boosting funding for research and development, plus higher corporate taxes to pay for the package.

title: Black Executives Push Companies to Battle GOP State Voting Laws
summary: Delta CEO also takes tougher position on new Georgia law, drawing retort from state's governor. Dozens of prominent Black executives called on corporations to fight Republican-led legislation they say would limit voting access for Black voters in numerous states, and Delta Air Lines Inc.'s CEO publicly clashed with Georgia's governor over a similar law passed there last week.

title: SEC Probes Trading by Archegos That Rattled Stock Market
summary: Investigation into fund is preliminary, say people familiar with the matter. WASHINGTON-Securities regulators are investigating trading at Archegos Capital Management, the fund that made highly leveraged bets on stocks and then collapsed last week, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Corporate Covid 'Windfalls' Are a Myth
summary: Some big companies rose to the occasion during the pandemic and did well. But there were losers too.. Now that its debt-funded relief program has become law, the Biden administration is looking to bankroll even bigger spending programs-the American Jobs Act, announced Wednesday, calls for higher taxes on corporations, and another bill is reportedly coming soon calling for higher taxes on wealthy individuals. The usual narrative pushing tax hikes is that the rich should pay their "fair share." But President Biden has introduced a new one: that the rich got windfalls during the pandemic while ordinary people suffered.

title: Build Infrastructure With Private Cash
summary: Instead of tax increases, why not finance some of the plan with public-private partnerships?. President Biden unveiled his $2.3 trillion infrastructure proposal on Wednesday, planning to fund it mostly via huge corporate tax increases, with the rest apparently from more federal borrowing. But if the White House and Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg truly want a bipartisan bill, they should invite private capital to play a major role in paying for portions of the plan. That would reduce the extent of federal tax increases and borrowing.

title: Biden's Election-Reform Deception
summary: He has his facts wrong on Iowa and Georgia and applies standards inconsistently.. In last week's press conference, President Biden labeled Republican efforts to reform state election laws in Georgia and Iowa as "un-American" and "sick." That charge is malarkey, to use one of the president's favorite words.

title: Rogers Hornsby's Unbreakable Record
summary: For a five-year period in the 1920s, he hit better than .400. That won't happen again.. Baseball is rooted in the records established by great players. Many claim that Joe DiMaggio's 56-games hitting streak is the record most likely never to be broken. But for many years fans believed Babe Ruth's 60 home-run season was a mark that would stand forever. Then Roger Maris hit 61 in 1961. That record, too, has since been broken-multiple times, though not without controversy.

title: 'Rescuing the Planet' Review: Harder, Greener, Faster, Smarter
summary: Could a 'Hard Green' commitment to the environment allow half the globe's lands to be protected from development?. Two decades ago, Peter Huber surprised his fellow libertarians and conservatives with a book urging them to become environmentalists. By that he didn't mean joining Greenpeace. He divided environmentalists into two categories: Hard Green (the title of his book) and Soft Green. The mainstream environmental movement was dominated by Soft Greens hostile to capitalism and new technologies who wanted to limit energy consumption and economic growth.

title: Businesses Take a Hurry-Up-and-Wait Approach to AI
summary: It can take decades for transformational technologies to yield real-world results, says Stanford's Erik Brynjolfsson. The pandemic has accelerated the commercial use of artificial intelligence at every level, with companies in some industries pulling ahead of others, according to Erik Brynjolfsson, director of the Stanford Digital Economy Lab.

title: Joe Biden, Which Side Are You On?
summary: In ProgressiveWorld, everyone becomes a de-facto member of the teachers union. It won't work.. With about 15 minutes left in the hour Joe Biden allotted last week for his once-only press conference, the president sort of ran out of steam for questions and filibustered the time remaining by delivering his campaign speech. After Mr. Biden revived the line, "I am running for three reasons," he invoked the middle class. The middle class, he said, "built America, and unions built them."

title: Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 Vaccine 100% Effective in Study of 12- to 15-Year-Olds
summary: Study didn't find any major safety issues with the shot, which could be up for regulatory authorization in coming weeks. The Covid-19 vaccine from Pfizer Inc. and BioNTech SE safely protects children between the ages of 12 and 15, the companies said, results likely to lead to inoculations within that age group before this summer.

title: France's Macron Orders New Nationwide Lockdown
summary: President's pandemic management is shaking confidence in his leadership 13 months before next election. PARIS-French President Emmanuel Macron announced a national lockdown Wednesday, closing schools and nonessential businesses, amid mounting public frustration over his government's handling of the pandemic.

title: Rita Hart Drops Challenge to Narrow Loss in Iowa Congressional Race
summary: Democrat had lost election by just six votes; GOP Rep. Mariannette Miller-Meeks took office in January. WASHINGTON-Democratic House candidate Rita Hart said she was dropping the challenge to her narrow election loss in Iowa, after her effort drew increasing concern among Democrats on Capitol Hill.

title: Biden Calls for $50 Billion to Boost U.S. Chip Industry
summary: Officials cite need to counter threat from China, but opponents say industry can succeed without tax dollars. title: Risk Panel to Address Vulnerabilities From 2020 Market Meltdown
summary: Financial Stability Oversight Council meets for first time during Biden administration. WASHINGTON-Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen convened a council of regulators tasked with monitoring the stability of the financial system, homing in on risks that emerged during the market turmoil of a year ago when the coronavirus pandemic hit the U.S. economy.

title: Family Offices Like Archegos Take Big Risks Like Hedge Funds

summary: On an evocative, ballad-heavy album, the singer reckons with her 2018 overdose and charts a path forward.

title: Like an Open Book
summary: Maya Lin's redesign of Smith College's Neilson Library is defined by transparency, accessibility and luminosity. Northampton, Mass.

title: 'Atlantic Crossing' Review: Harboring Royals and Passions
summary: A 'Masterpiece' series dramatizes the unexpected relationship between Crown Princess Martha of Norway and President Franklin Roosevelt. The opening scenes of "Atlantic Crossing" could scarcely be merrier, circumstances notwithstanding. It is the period of Nazi conquest throughout Europe. Crown Princess Martha of Norway (Sofia Helin) and husband Crown Prince Olav (Tobias Santelmann) are enjoying a sexual liaison on a passenger train in the U.S.-the country to which they fled in fear of an expected German invasion. Their fears were well grounded-the Germans invaded Norway in 1940. Martha had expected a new and peaceful life in America, and found one, of sorts, for a time. What she never expected was the heady experience of a circle of political and social relationships that would bring her into close contact with President Franklin Roosevelt. So close that he invited the crown princess to make her home at the White House with her three children-a gesture that led to an ever-deepening strain of suspicion and gossip about the nature of their relationship.

title: Matt Pottinger on China and U.S. Business
summary: In "Beijing Targets American Business" Matt Pottinger quotes Chinese President Xi Jinping in 2013 describing the ultimate triumph of socialism over all other economic systems.. In "Beijing Targets American Business" (op-ed, March 27), Matt Pottinger quotes Chinese President Xi Jinping in 2013 describing the ultimate triumph of socialism over all other economic systems. The religious fervor of the socialist faithful is widespread throughout the world including the U.S. President Xi doesn't seem able to admit that China under Mao and up until Paramount Leader Deng Xiaoping had a crippled economy. Deng famously said: "Let some people get rich first" to move the country forward. The pro-business policies rocketed many Chinese into billionaire status. The booming economy has allowed Mr. Xi to militarize capitalism and make China the second largest economy in the world.

title: U.S. Should Follow EUâs Lead on ESG Policy
summary: The European Union is setting a standard for environmental, social and governance (ESG) disclosures that the U.S. needs to work quickly to catch up to.. title: AI Set to Reshape Workplace as Physical Offices Open Up
summary: AI can help support a range of safety-monitoring tools, says Adam Stanley, chief information officer and chief digital officer, Cushman & Wakefield. Encouraged by the rapid pace of Covid-19 vaccinations, employers planning to reopen physical workplaces face a number of unique challenges-not least keeping elevators safe, says Adam Stanley, chief information officer and chief digital officer at commercial-real-estate-services giant Cushman & Wakefield PLC.

title: Science's Real-World Issue Is Not Marketing
summary: I think that the problem Neil deGrasse Tyson assigns to bad marketing is more attributable to prominent scientists overstepping the bounds of their fields.. I think that the problem Neil deGrasse Tyson assigns to bad marketing is more attributable to prominent scientists overstepping the bounds of their fields ("What I've Learned From the Pandemic Year: Science Needs Better Marketing," Review, March 20). Science should inform, not dictate, politics. Science is never settled, so it's OK to challenge scientists on the facts as well as their predictions.

title: When the Economic Cure Is Worse Than the Disease
summary: The real catastrophe the country is facing isn't the alleged disasters cited by Democrats, but rather the Democrats' policy "solutions.". Daniel Henninger's "Biden Abandons Normalcy" (Wonder Land, March 18) accurately describes the Democrats' strategy as pointing to alleged impending disasters that require immediate action in Washington, such as Covid-19 recovery and climate change. The irony is that the real catastrophe the country is facing isn't the alleged disasters cited by Democrats, but rather the Democrats' policy "solutions" and the staggering debt, high taxes, ravaged energy sector and reduced economic growth that they create. In area after area, I believe that the Democrats' cure is a much greater threat than the disease.

title: After Ban on Foreign Fans, an Olympic Refund Fight Is Just Beginning
summary: Organizers and authorized ticket resellers are at odds over who should bear the costs of 20% service charges consumers paid on tickets. The answer may be: ticket holders.. The Tokyo hosts of this summer's Olympic Games are in a standoff with ticket-selling middlemen over who should bear the costs of hefty service charges on hundreds of thousands of tickets to an event that will ban foreign spectators because of the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Memo to Biden: Stimulus Is Easy. Investment Is Hard.
summary: The president's infrastructure plan could boost long-term growth-if targeted effectively. President Biden's ambitious agenda to remake the American economy comes in two stages. Stage one, the $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan, is intended to jolt the economy back to life with a huge dollop of old-fashioned Keynesian demand-side stimulus. Mr. Biden should be pleased with the results: as checks have landed in consumer bank accounts, growth has begun to surge.

title: S&P 500 Rises but Just Misses New Record

summary: The opposition politician says he has suffered debilitating back pain and has been subjected to sleep deprivation since being imprisoned in February. title: New York Legalizes Marijuana: What to Know
summary: The state becomes the 15th in the U.S. to legalize the recreational use of marijuana. Gov. State lawmakers say 20% of the tax revenue generated from marijuana sales-which is eventually projected to be $350 million a year-would be devoted to drug education. An additional 40% of revenue will be directed to education aid and 40% will be dedicated to a fund that will make grants for social equity.

title: An Auschwitz Survivor Dies in a New York Nursing Home
summary: At 94, Felicia Friedman succumbed to Covid-19 and bureaucratic bungling.. Felicia Friedman survived the Nazis. She survived the Red Army, dodging her way across Eastern Europe after World War II. She survived immigration and a new life in America. The only thing she didn't survive was a Long Island nursing home infected with Covid-19. She died on May 19, 2020, at 94.

title: For Freedom's Sake, Rate Hong Kong
summary: The Fraser Institute, unlike Heritage, will measure its descent into tyranny and domination.. The people of Hong Kong deserve to have their descent into tyranny recorded. History also deserves a record of the Chinese Communist Party's suppression of what was once the freest place on the planet. One international index has already expunged Hong Kong, but the Economic Freedom of the World Index, published by Canada's Fraser Institute, and the Human Freedom Index, co-published by Fraser and the Cato Institute, won't abandon Hong Kong.

title: Cardboard Boxes Have Never Been in More Demand
summary: Producers of corrugated board boost prices, adding to supply-chain woes as economy reopens. It wasn't just you. Americans consumed more corrugated cardboard boxes than ever last year.

title: OK, Doomer
summary: Government experts still advocate restrictions, ignore collateral damage.. Maybe it's too much to hope that government health experts have learned something in the past year about the massive unintended consequences of lockdowns and the paucity of evidence demonstrating their effectiveness. But Monday's White House teleconference with the Biden Covid team could almost have been mistaken for a March 2020 event-complete with government doctors stoking fear, urging restrictions on liberty and not even bothering to address costs and benefits.

title: Why Outdoor Incense Is the Expert Garden-Party Tip
summary: To create instant atmosphere, professional party planners swear by long-burning sticks of sophisticated scents like cedar, clove and jasmine. While the jury is still out on the question of whether stinky, smoke-born citronella significantly repels mosquitoes, new versions of al fresco scent aim higher-bringing instant atmosphere and more sophisticated fragrances (like clove, cedarwood and clary sage) to the party. title: How to Improve Your Work-Life Balance
summary: Most Popular News. Feeling overworked? You are not alone. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development's 2020 Better Life Index found that the U.S. ranks 30th out of 40 countries in terms of time devoted to leisure and personal care. With fewer Americans commuting to workplaces during the coronavirus pandemic, many are using that time to work even more, leading some to feel burned out. In a September survey of 310 organizations by the Conference Board, 46% of respondents said their work-life balance had decreased. Achieving a balance between your working hours and home life may seem unattainable, but consultants, burnout management coaches and work-life researchers say there are steps you can take to help make the most of your days.

summary: Buzzer has secured rights to stream snippets of NHL games and PGA golf on smartphones. Sports leagues and TV networks are finding it increasingly challenging to reach young fans, many of whom don't have cable subscriptions and are content to devour game highlights on social media.

summary: Stock futures wavered between gains and losses ahead of the rollout of President Biden's multitrillion dollar spending program. Happy Wednesday. Here's what we're watching in today's trading session.

title: The Best Spring Trips to Watch Wildlife-From Whales to Flamingos
summary: As the animal kingdom emerges from winter, here are three top spots in North and Central America to spy grizzly bears, orcas, wolves and more. SPRING FLINGS aren't just for humans. As much of the Northern Hemisphere greens up this month, animals, from Caribbean flamingos to Hawaii's humpback whales, are making moves. With travel on a vaccination-fueled rebound, a commune with nature might make for a great first trip out of lockdown. You won't have to rough it, either. Any number of hotels and resorts offer both creature comforts-along with the creatures. Staff will book fauna-focused tours or lead the safaris themselves. As North and Central America's wildlife begins to stir in the coming weeks, here are some choice spots to find them.

title: From Selena Gomez to St. Vincent, the Best Songs You Should Be Listening to Right Now
summary: Here's WSJ.'s monthly roundup of new pop releases: everything that's grabbing our attention, making us think or getting us dancing. 2021 is set to be a big year for Michelle Zauner, who releases indie pop music under the moniker Japanese Breakfast. This month, she released the first single from her third album, Jubilee, out June 4. "Be Sweet" is a celebratory synth-pop track about overcoming relationship insecurity in favor of compassion. On April 20, Zauner will release her first memoir, Crying in H Mart, a book about grief and searching for the tastes of her childhood.

title: H&M, Under Attack in China, Sticks to Stance That Angered Beijing
summary: Fashion giant says 20 stores have been closed in China after brand was targeted by government and on social media. The chief executive of H&M Hennes and Mauritz AB said the fashion giant wants to be a "responsible buyer," standing by a human-rights position that angered Beijing and triggered the brand's disappearance from China's internet.

title: Will Xiaomi Be the Apple of Electric Vehicles?
summary: Chinese smartphone maker bets consumer technology companies can also design attractive EVs. A well-loved smartphone maker is going into electric vehicles. Apple ? Not yet. China's Xiaomi -the world's third-largest smartphone maker-is barreling ahead into car making.

title: Startup Productiv Raises $45 Million in New Funding
summary: Company says its platform, which helps CIOs measure employee app engagement, experienced boost during pandemic. Productiv Inc., a startup that helps chief information officers manage the many software applications in use at a company, has closed $45 million in venture capital funding, amid revenue growth partly due to the pandemic.

title: Covid-19 Vaccinations Are Picking Up Pace, but New Cases Are Still Rising
summary: Health officials cite expanded reopenings, pandemic fatigue, variants as reasons behind the recent uptick in infections. The supply of Covid-19 vaccines in the U.S. is increasing with each week, and the pace of vaccinations is picking up. States are opening up eligibility for the vaccines sooner, too, allowing more Americans an opportunity to get the shot.

title: Suez Canal Pilots Under Scrutiny Amid Effort to Clear Backlog
summary: Resume Subscription. ISMAILIA, Egypt-With ships moving again in the Suez Canal after the Ever Given was unstuck, the Egyptian sailors tasked with piloting huge vessels through one of the world's busiest waterways are back at work-and facing growing scrutiny.

title: Australia to Build Its Own Guided Missiles
summary: U.S. ally plans to invest $761 million on program. SYDNEY-Australia is accelerating efforts to join the ranks of guided-missile manufacturers and become less reliant on imports from the U.S. and Europe after the pandemic exposed weaknesses in global supply chains.

title: SPAC Excitement Fades as Historic Quarter Ends
summary: It is now common for SPACs to dip below their debut price and gyrate around that level. SPAC mania is taking a breather.

title: NFL Teams Are Giving Up on Quarterbacks Faster Than Ever
summary: There's no longer a belief in being patient when it comes to the most important position in football. Just 14 months ago, there was a moment when every quarterback wanted to be Jimmy Garoppolo. He had a bright future. He had a rich contract. He was minutes away from being able to call himself a Super Bowl champion.

title: Archegos's Collapse Is a Wakeup Call for Regulators
summary: Post-crisis capital requirements have saved Credit Suisse and Nomura from more serious problems while also pushing risk into darker corners of the financial system. The big damage from Archegos's collapse seems to have been limited to Credit Suisse and Nomura. But that doesn't mean all is well in the financial system.

title: Singapore Explores Getting in on SPACs
summary: Stock exchange starts public consultation on the publicly listed shell companies that seek to invest in-and merge with-private companies. Singapore is trying to get a piece of the red-hot market for blank-check companies.

title: Payments Companies Play Hide-the-Crypto
summary: Visa and PayPal introduce stealthy ways to make digital coins part of everyday transactions. Bitcoin and other digital currencies' best bet to become major actors in the world of payments might be to stay behind the scenes.

title: BlackRock Raises $3 Billion for First Dedicated Secondary Strategy
summary: Asset-management giant has raised it first ever fund to buy secondhand private-equity stakes. BlackRock Inc. has raised $3 billion to invest in the private-equity secondary market, as the world's largest asset manager seeks to expand its presence in illiquid alternative investments.

title: Apple Supports Independent Artists With New Investment
summary: Tech giant teams up with artist-services company UnitedMasters, an alternative to the major label system. Apple Inc. is investing in independent music artists.

title: Traders Worry Reopening Will Stifle NFT Rally
summary: About $1.3 billion of nonfungible tokens have traded through ethereum network this year, dwarfing 2020 activity. Prices for digital art and collectibles soared in the first quarter, lifted by traders' exuberance for volatile wagers from to GameStop . Now many are wondering whether those gains can hold as people prepare to leave home more in the coming months.

title: America's Imports Are Stuck on Ships Floating Just Off Los Angeles
summary: Tens of thousands of containers holding millions of dollars' worth of goods are stuck offshore, within sight of docks jammed with still more containers. The giant container ship that blocked the Suez Canal for six days was freed Monday, but another bottleneck in the supply chain remains, this one in Southern California.

title: Japanese Investors Accelerated the Treasury Selloff
summary: Banks focused on booking profits by the Japanese fiscal year-end unloaded bonds in recent weeks. The sharp rise in Treasury yields in recent weeks looked like a test of whether the Federal Reserve can keep interest rates low after the economy regains its footing.

title: Vaccinations of Pregnant Mothers Protect Newborns, Studies Suggest
summary: One study also found antibodies in the breast milk of vaccinated mothers. Pregnant women who get the coronavirus vaccine pass their antibodies on to their newborns, recent studies suggest, a promising sign that babies can acquire from their mothers some protection against Covid-19.

title: Suez Canal Opens, but Shipping Will Be Snarled for Months
Former Senior Merck Executive Hired by Life-Sciences Firm
summary: Michael Nally named partner at Flagship Pioneering and CEO of a startup that leverages machine-learning to develop biotechnology drugs. Former Merck & Co. executive Michael Nally, who was a candidate to be its next chief executive, will join life-sciences platforms firm Flagship Pioneering and take the helm of one of its startup companies.

title: China's Consumers Boost Its Economic Recovery
summary: After a year in which manufacturing drove the rebound, services and construction activity jumped in March. BEIJING-China's economic recovery picked up a surprising amount of steam in March, boosted by strong domestic consumption and unquenchable foreign demand for Chinese-made goods.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Rep. Gaetz Is Investigated for Alleged Relationship With Underage Girl
summary: Probe started last year into whether Republican congressman and vocal Trump ally broke federal sex-trafficking laws, people familiar with the matter say. The Justice Department since last year has been investigating whether Republican Rep. Matt Gaetz of Florida had a sexual relationship with a 17-year-old girl and paid her to travel with him, people familiar with the matter said.

title: John Kerry Headed to India, U.A.E. for Climate Talks
summary: Trip comes ahead of international climate summit President Biden is hosting next month. WASHINGTON-U. S. climate envoy John Kerry is planning to travel to India and the United Arab Emirates in the coming days to increase the Biden administration's pursuit of deeper international commitments to address climate change, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: G. Gordon Liddy, Mastermind of the Watergate Burglary, Dies at 90
summary: Liddy was convicted of conspiracy, burglary and illegal wiretapping for his role in the Watergate burglary. WASHINGTON-G. Gordon Liddy, a mastermind of the Watergate burglary and a radio talk show host after emerging from prison, died Tuesday at age 90.

title: FTC Sues to Block Illumina's Deal for Grail in Antitrust Test
summary: The case would set up a major test for U.S. antitrust enforcement. WASHINGTON-The Federal Trade Commission filed suit Tuesday to block Illumina Inc.'s planned $7.1 billion acquisition of a company developing an early stage cancer-detection test, in the latest signal that the U.S. is entering a period of more aggressive antitrust enforcement.
